text: 2. *Diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) work means challenging prevailing norms*. We also have a lot of informal community knowledge and norms that aren't explicitly written down and can have the effect of being intimidating / exclusionary to newcomers. And we can definitely be more proactive about DEI efforts, which means challenging our assumptions of how this community and ecosystem ought to grow and a conscious effort to avoid homophily. Inclusivity means we have to do better than "let it grow organically and they will come", because that is a recipe for attracting only like-minded people who have the same privileged access to the current community network and the bandwidth to work on FOSS as side projects. Written norms like the CoC are one way to codify acceptable behavior as policy to justify moderation interventions.

text: I've personally struggled with the problems of unpaid administrative and mentoring work - we need more to be better about DEI but if it becomes a burden, volunteers will drop out. The current issues we have around homophily are not intentional but emergent from the eternal problem of "I'm a volunteer and I only have the bandwidth to do this much", but we have to acknowledge the discriminatory outcome from this approach.
